Award.AwardTitle: Strategic Direction for Mathematics Learning by Inquiry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mathematics learning by inquiry (MLI) employs active learning techniques, incorporation of meaningful applications of mathematics, and attention to broader academic skills. A growing evidence base indicates that MLI can have a positive impact on student learning and success in undergraduate mathematics. The goal of this project is to build a larger national community of instructors who employ MLI and education researchers who study MLI. To this end, this workshop project will bring leaders and representatives from among the MLI instructor community together with leaders and representatives from the research in undergraduate mathematics education community (RUME). By bringing together leaders and representatives from both the MLI and RUME communities, this project will form an initial step to forge a more formal and symbiotic collaboration between these two communities.

Specifically, the workshops will produce a strategic plan for the Initiative for Mathematics Learning by Inquiry. This plan will focus on building a collaborative cycle through which the MLI initiative inspires education research projects, which in turn are used to inform the MLI initiative. The workshops themselves will be structured to employ active engagement and inquiry oriented problem solving. Each of an expected thirty participants will be actively engaged in the process with each having an opportunity to make a substantial contribution. Participants will develop national goals for a MLI initiative, identify strategies to reach these goals, and establish a strong collaboration between these communities to improve undergraduate mathematics education. This collaborative effort will strengthen the ability of the MLI initiative to support effective, sustainable, and scalable reforms in undergraduate mathematics education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the development of a three-year strategic plan through a collaborative project between practitioners of mathematics learning by inquiry and researchers in undergraduate mathematics education (RUME). The outcome provides the Initiative for Mathematics Learning by Inquiry (MLI) to provide broad community input and support  to sustain the advances in Inquiry Learning made over the past 20 years  and to expand to a larger national community of researchers, teachers and practitioners of  Inquiry Learning. Through a diverse selection of participants and a broad view of implementation of learning by inquiry that optimizes learning in mathematics classrooms by 1) increased use of challenging active learning techniques, 2) incorporation of meaningful applications of the mathematical concepts being studied, and 3) attention to the development of broader academic sucess skills, the goal of using Learning by Inquiry is to develop a seamless pedagogy through K-20 mathematics education and empower all students to succeed and have better preparation for careers. 

Policymakers, professional organizations, and educational researchers alike have decisively and uniformly proposed the widespread adoption of more inquiry-oriented, student-centered methods of instruction across all levels of the mathematics curriculum. This project is bringing together central communities in a collaborative plan to address this challenge. Inquiry learning techniques have been shown to be particularly beneficial for underprepared, minority, female, and first-generation students. The impact of enhancing and increasing the use of inquiry learning, informed by mathematics education research and evaluation, will have impact on thousands of students each year who will be better positioned for academic and workforce success as a result of their increased experience with learning by inquiry. The goals and objectives are driven by  sustainable approaches for for a potentially transformative impact on mathematics teaching and learning.
